channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Europeans push back at US over claim they face 'civilizational erasure'
item.description: A top European Union official on Sunday rejected the notion that Europe faces "civilizational erasure," pushing back at criticism of the continent by the Trump administration.
item.content:encoded:
A top European Union official on Sunday rejected the notion that Europe faces "civilizational erasure," pushing back at criticism of the continent by the Trump administration.

(Image credit: Michael Probst)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: FBI: DNA from glove near Guthrie home appears to match glove worn by suspect
item.description: The FBI says a glove containing DNA was found about two miles from Nancy Guthrie's Arizona home and appears to match those worn by a masked person outside her front door the night she vanished.
item.content:encoded:
The FBI says a glove containing DNA was found about two miles from Nancy Guthrie's Arizona home and appears to match those worn by a masked person outside her front door the night she vanished.

(Image credit: Ty O'Neil)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Trump's border czar says a 'small' security force will stay in Minnesota
item.description: Tom Homan says this federal force will stay "for a short period of time" to protect immigration agents who remain as the sweeping crackdown draws down.
item.content:encoded:
Tom Homan says this federal force will stay "for a short period of time" to protect immigration agents who remain as the sweeping crackdown draws down.

(Image credit: Julia Demaree Nikhinson)
item.dc:creator: Alina Selyukh

item.title: At least 6,000 killed over 3 days during RSF attack on Sudan's el-Fasher, UN says
item.description: More than 6,000 people were killed in over three days when a Sudanese paramilitary group unleashed "a wave of intense violence" in Sudan's Darfur region in late October, according to the UN.
item.content:encoded:
More than 6,000 people were killed in over three days when a Sudanese paramilitary group unleashed "a wave of intense violence" in Sudan's Darfur region in late October, according to the UN.

(Image credit: Mahmoud Hjaj)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Obama responds to Trump sharing racist AI video depicting him as an ape
item.description: "There doesn't seem to be any shame about this among people who used to feel like you had to have some sort of decorum," Obama said in an interview that was posted on YouTube Saturday.
item.content:encoded:
"There doesn't seem to be any shame about this among people who used to feel like you had to have some sort of decorum," Obama said in an interview that was posted on YouTube Saturday.

(Image credit: Scott Olson)
item.dc:creator: Chandelis Duster

item.title: Why do humans kiss?
item.description: Matilda Brindle, an evolutionary biologist at the University of Oxford, explains.
item.content:encoded: Matilda Brindle, an evolutionary biologist at the University of Oxford, explains.
item.dc:creator: Emily Kwong

item.title: Photos: The flying doctors of Lesotho won't let their wings be clipped
item.description: This band of airborne health workers bring essential medical care to isolated communities in the southern African nation. In addition to turbulence, they face a new obstacle: budget cuts.
item.content:encoded:
This band of airborne health workers bring essential medical care to isolated communities in the southern African nation. In addition to turbulence, they face a new obstacle: budget cuts.

(Image credit: Tommy Trenchard for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Tommy Trenchard

item.title: Rockstar athletes like Ilia Malinin often get 'the yips' at the Olympics. It can make them stronger
item.description: Ilia Malinin's painful falls at the Milan Cortina Games follow in a long tradition of great U.S. athletes who get the "yips" or the "twisties" during the Olympics.
item.content:encoded:
Ilia Malinin's painful falls at the Milan Cortina Games follow in a long tradition of great U.S. athletes who get the "yips" or the "twisties" during the Olympics.

(Image credit: Francisco Seco)
item.dc:creator: Brian Mann

item.title: U.S. Alpine skier Mikaela Shiffrin finishes another Olympic race without a medal
item.description: U.S. Alpine skier Mikaela Shiffrin looks unstoppable everywhere except the Olympics. She's running out of chances to medal at the Milan Cortina Games.
item.content:encoded:
U.S. Alpine skier Mikaela Shiffrin looks unstoppable everywhere except the Olympics. She's running out of chances to medal at the Milan Cortina Games.

(Image credit: Marco Trovati)
item.dc:creator: Brian Mann

item.title: 'Major travel impacts' expected as winter storm watch issued for northern California
item.description: As people travel for the holiday weekend, much of Northern California is under a winter storm watch, with communities bracing for several feet of snow.
item.content:encoded:
As people travel for the holiday weekend, much of Northern California is under a winter storm watch, with communities bracing for several feet of snow.

(Image credit: Justin Sullivan)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
